required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Lay Therapist Effectiveness With Displaced Persons Kurdish Iraq
clinical_study.official_title: Lay Therapist Effectiveness With Displaced Persons Kurdish Iraq: Promising Exploratory Results for Global Mental Health Access

brief_summary.textblock: Negative mental health effects of war exposure and displacement are pervasive, but many displaced persons and refugees in low-and-middle income countries lack access to evidence-based treatments. Community lay-therapists are a promising solution for the global mental health field. However, in spite of results from randomized-control trials, no research to-date has examined the external validity of community-led lay-therapist effectiveness. In this exploratory study, longitudinal data at three time points were collected from 28 Arabic-speaking displaced persons (nineteen women and nine men, ages 18-57) seeking mental health services from the Jiyan Foundation: a non-profit founded and based in Kurdish Iraq. Lay therapists trained in evidence-based treatments upon being hired operated largely independently of supervision from foreign clinicians. Participants in weekly psychotherapy completed the Posttraumatic Stress Checklist (PCL-5) and the Psychological Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) at baseline, one month, and three months, as well as a modified measure assessing traumatic exposure, purpose-in-life, and a modified Afghan Daily Stressors Scale at baseline to assess for moderators of change over time.

arm_group.description: Participants seeking treatment completed longitudinal data

intervention.description: Community Therapists Used CBT and EMDR Interventions

study_pop.textblock: Participants were 18-years-or-older Arabic speakers displaced from their homes in either Central/Southern Iraq or Syria and now residing in Kurdish Iraq and seeking treatment for mental health difficulties.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Must speak Arabic fluently; must be seeking mental health services at the Jiyan Foundation
Exclusion Criteria:
- No Arabic proficiency; under 18 years

patient_data.ipd_description: Dataset is available with participant answers, but original forms are not to be shared as some personal information was written in notes (i.e. names)
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Data will be available for two years after reporting and by request following.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Data is publicly available at OSF for download, or can be requested by contacting blackwell@unm.edu
